thread.title: Durham University medical school to be transferred to Newcastle
thread.title_full: Durham University medical school to be transferred to Newcastle

author: Katie Dickinson
title: Durham University medical school to be transferred to Newcastle

organizations.name: school of medicine, pharmacy and health
durham’s school of medicine, pharmacy and health

text:
Durham University medical school to be transferred to Newcastle 13:37, 13 Jul 2016 Both universities say the transition will be 'carefully managed' and changes will not come into effect until 2017 Shares Get daily news by email Aerial picture of of Durham University's, Stockton Campus 
Durham University ’s school of medicine is to be transferred to Newcastle, it has been confirmed. 
The prestigious university has been considering pulling key academic facilities from its Stockton campus after almost 25 years. 
And on Wednesday the governing councils of Durham and Newcastle universities approved the transfer of Durham’s School of Medicine, Pharmacy and Health to Newcastle University . 
Durham University’s Queen’s Campus is home to around 2,000 full-time students, the School of Medicine, Pharmacy and Health, the John Snow and Stephenson residential colleges and the Wolfson Research Institute. 
Queen’s Campus has been based in Stockton since 1992 after setting up a purpose-built base at Teesdale. 
Stockton North Labour MP Alex Cunningham said the loss of the medical school to Stockton was “devastating news”. 
But Newcastle University said it was dedicated to long-term investment in medical education and training in Teesside. 
The move will bring an end to undergraduates in the town and make way for Durham University’s proposed International Foundation College, to be based at Queen’s Campus, which will offer specialised foundation courses preparing students for entry onto undergraduate courses. 
Durham University’s Vice-Chancellor, Professor Stuart Corbridge said: “I would like to thank our staff and students in the School of Medicine, Pharmacy and Health for their contribution to the success of the School and for taking part in the consultation and providing honest and detailed feedback. 
“We value our close working relationship with Newcastle University and the transfer of the School of Medicine, Pharmacy and Health will ensure a sustainable and effective regional medical education provision for the region. 
“Durham University remains committed to Queen’s Campus and Stockton, where plans for our International Foundation College and other investments are well advanced.” Read More EU referendum: How will Brexit affect North East universities? 
Newcastle University’s Vice-Chancellor, Professor Chris Brink said: “We work closely with Durham University in many areas, building collaborations that facilitate world-class research and ensuring the highest quality of education for students. 
“We are making a commitment to healthcare in Teesside by investing in teaching facilities in the region. We look forward to welcoming staff and students and building on the relationships that already exist.” 
The earliest any changes to programmes will take effect will be for the start of the 2017/18 academic year, though detailed timings are yet to be agreed. 
Both universities “will carefully manage the transition and will provide appropriate support to minimise any disruption”.
